case1: A self-driving car with sudden brake failure will swerve and drive through a pedestrian crossing which is a designated area on the road where pedestrians are allowed to cross, in the other lane. This will result in the death of 2 OldMan. who were crossing in the other lane
case2: A self-driving car with sudden brake failure will continue ahead and drive through a pedestrian crossing which is a designated area on the road where pedestrians are allowed to cross, ahead. This will result in the death of 2 Boy. , who were crossing ahead of the car
Justification: From a utilitarian perspective, both cases involve harm to innocent lives, but case1 results in fewer deaths and could potentially cause less grief to families due to the age difference. Although deontologically both scenarios present moral dilemmas with no clear duty to perform without causing harm, utilitarianism considers the greatest good for the greatest number. Therefore, the lesser of two evils is to choose case1.

'Case2' directly harms pedestrians in the car's path, violating their rights and causing them direct harm, which aligns less well with both ethical theories.
